head.supplied: Monga ¶ 12/7/90. ¶ ¶ […] ¶ ¶ By this mail I forward a small fruiting specimen of a Eucalyptus, which I found yesterday as a windfall on a very steep mountainside in a wild region, where I don't thin...

div.p: MRS 203/2, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921, 90/404 Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney

By this mail I forward a small fruiting specimen of a Eucalyptus, which I found yesterday as a windfall on a very steep mountainside in a wild region, where I don't think ever anybody has been. I don't remember to have seen this particular kind of fruit before, and unfortunately have only three numbers of the "Eucalyptographia" here to refer to, therefore I send a specimen to you at once, as also to the Baron, in order to hear from either side whether the matter demands further investigation, so that I should search for the particular tree, have one cut down to obtain specimens as complete as possible, as well as bark, timber and kino. […] I think the fruit comes from a tree which in bark and other respects looks much like the "White Ash" from the Tantawanglo Mntn. and other localities reported last winter. […] I will also ask the Baron to let me know as soon as possible about it. […]
